question: In the solar system, which planet has the longest year?

content.source_1: Kepler’s third law: For planets orbiting the same star, the orbital period increases with the orbit’s semimajor axis (greater average Sun–planet distance implies a longer year).
content.source_2: Neptune is the outermost of the eight recognized planets; it has the largest semimajor axis around the Sun.
content.source_3: Neptune is a planet in the Solar System that orbits the Sun.
content.source_4: Jupiter is the most massive planet in the Solar System; its mass exceeds that of all the other planets combined.
content.source_5: More massive bodies have greater inertia: for the same applied force, they undergo less acceleration (Newton’s second law).
content.source_6: A planet remains in orbit because the Sun’s gravity provides the centripetal force that keeps it moving along a curved path.
